column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=The Onion : An interview with ' America 's Finest News Source '
#Text=Sunday , November 25 , 2007
#Text=How The Onion writes an issue
#Text=This exclusive interview features first - hand journalism by a Wikinews reporter .
#Text=See the collaboration page for more details .
#Text=How do you decide on the stories ?
#Text=We do everything backwards here .
#Text=We start with the headline and then flesh out the story , as opposed to The New York Times , which writes the issue and then has a headline editor to make it snappy .
#Text=We start with a joke .
#Text=We read about six hundred to eight hundred headline ideas on a Monday coming from our staff and a small group of writers outside — a contributing core .
#Text=We whittle that down on a Monday to about a hundred , come in Tuesday and pick an issue and brainstorm with the whole editorial staff ; all fifteen of us .
#Text=Then we assign a headline to a specific writer to execute .
#Text=We go through a number of drafts and then have the editors pick it up and assign the photojournalism aspect of it to our graphic design team , who adds the visual aspect to it .
#Text=The editors punch it up over the last couple of days and then it goes out over the Internet and into the print edition .

#Text=So you do n’t have writers coming up with a story and headline , but you will instead have a team of writers choosing the best headlines and then assign it to a particular writer who was not necessarily involved ?

#Text=Writers will occasionally write their own headlines , but we come up with a list of 15 or 20 headline ideas , what we think will make a good story and then we assign it based upon what people ’s writing strengths are .
#Text=We have some people who are great at politics ; some people we give all the war stuff to ; someone who is in charge of the Britney Spears story of the week — the entertainment stories .
#Text=The headlines
#Text=Editorial Manager Chet Clem and President Sean Mills .
#Text=Image : David Shankbone
#Text=It seems like some publications , like AM New York , always have a Britney Spears story ;
#Text=is there anything similar with The Onion where they continually revisit a topic or person ?
#Text=No , not necessarily .
#Text=We are a little less reactionary .
#Text=We tend to target the zeitgeist more than anything .
#Text=We ’ll hit the mainstream media ’s portrayal of the entertainment world as much as we ’ll hit characters in the entertainment world .
#Text=We ’ll attack People Magazine ’s coverage of Britney as much as Britney .

#Text=In an interview with Terry Gross , Stephen Colbert said of his time at Second City that they had decided on not doing political humor and , in particular , hackneyed political humor such as Ted Kennedy drinking jokes .
#Text=They felt it was overdone , mean - spirited and not funny .
#Text=Do your writers have similar rules of thumb ?
#Text=We do n’t have any rules or known lines we wo n’t cross .
#Text=We have an understanding based upon having the same writers in the back room for years , and those writers training the new writers as they come in .
#Text=There is an understanding in the room .
#Text=If it makes the room laugh , it probably ends up in the paper .

#Text=One example is we ran an article a couple of years back that was , " We heard from Tina McKenzie and Mario Lucero . Tina 's former Gliders team were part of the Sydney Paralegic Athletics team .

#Text=It ’s sort of like ,  Hmmm ... that ’s hilarious . That ’s really really funny " rather than people falling off their chairs .

column1: #Text=It ’s more subdued than I think what most people would expect .
#Text=It ’s more analytical and clinical ?
#Text=Not all the time , but it ca n’t be a laugh a minute .
#Text=Yeah , what you see on Studio 60 and 30 Rock , those are scripted writers rooms .
#Text=Everything is funny there .
#Text=There 's a lot of unfunny jokes that are told in a back room , that 's why they stay and die in that back room and do n’t go out in The Onion .
#Text=If someone is continually telling unfunny jokes , do you eventually fire them ?
#Text=That ’s why we are on the 10th floor to make sure they die when they get kicked out .
#Text=It can be a real mess on Broadway .
#Text=By the time you get to be a writer for The Onion , though , the odds are you are going to succeed because we make it pretty challenging .
#Text=You go through quite a bit .
#Text=You will already have demonstrated a pretty long successful record of writing stuff for us before you will be in that room on a daily basis .
#Text=But if somebody wakes up one morning and suddenly no longer is funny , then yeah , head first , out the door as quickly as possible , and as sadistically as possible .
